net.sf.mmm.client.ui.base.binding

Class UiDataBindingNone

  • java.lang.Object
    • net.sf.mmm.client.ui.base.binding.UiDataBindingNone
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    AttributeReadModified, AttributeReadValueAdvanced<Void>, AttributeWriteModified, AttributeWriteValueAdvanced<Void>, UiFeature, UiFeatureValidation<Void>, UiFeatureValue<Void>, UiFeatureValueAndValidation<Void>, UiDataBinding<Void>, AttributeReadValue<Void>, AttributeWriteValue<Void>, AbstractValidatableObject, HasValueValidators<Void>, ValidatableObject<Void>

    public class UiDataBindingNone
extends Object
implements UiDataBinding<Void>
    This is the implementation of UiDataBinding for no value (Void).
    Since:
    1.0.0
    Author:
    Joerg Hohwiller (hohwille at users.sourceforge.net)
    See Also:
    getInstance()

      • getInstance

        public static UiDataBinding<Void> getInstance()

        the singleton instance of this class.

      • getValueAndValidate

        public Void getValueAndValidate(ValidationState state)
        This method is a combination of AttributeReadValueAdvanced.getValue() and AbstractValidatableObject.validate(ValidationState). It is designed for API users implementing higher level dialog logic and is therefore easy to use. It performs a validation and only on success it returns the value.
        ATTENTION:
        The method design assumes that null is not a valid value. Never call this method with null as argument if <VALUE> is Void or anything else that considers null as a valid value. It should be used for high-level UI nodes such as entire input forms or (sub-)dialogs.
        Specified by:
        getValueAndValidate in interface UiFeatureValueAndValidation<Void>
        Parameters:
        state - is the ValidationState. Shall initially be created as new instance and passed on in case of recursive validations. May also be null and will then be created internally (in case you do not need the validation result).
        Returns:
        the actual value or null if the validation failed or null is the actual (valid) value.

      • getValueDirect

        public Void getValueDirect(Void template,
                           ValidationState state)
                    throws RuntimeException
        This method is a combination of AttributeReadValueAdvanced.getValueOrException(Object) and AbstractValidatableObject.validate(ValidationState). It allows more efficient implementations as determining and creating the value can be expensive. Saving changes requires validation AND on success getting the value, while already validation requires getting the value. For composite UI objects this effect would reinforce to multiply the number of calls to AttributeReadValueAdvanced.getValueOrException(Object).
        NOTE:
        This method is designed for implementors of composite UI objects. API users should only use UiFeatureValueAndValidation.getValueAndValidate(ValidationState).
        Specified by:
        getValueDirect in interface UiFeatureValueAndValidation<Void>
        Parameters:
        template - is the object where the data is filled in. May also be null - then this method will create a new instance.
        state - is the ValidationState. If null the validation will be omitted, otherwise an implicit validation is performed.
        Returns:
        the current value. May be null (esp. if invalid).
        Throws:
        RuntimeException - if state is null no validation is performed and input errors are directly thrown causing a fast fail. Otherwise if validation is performed all RuntimeException are catched and according validation failures are collected and visualized by the UI.

        true if the handler has been removed successfully, false if it was NOT registered and nothing has changed.

      • setValueForUser

        public void setValueForUser(Void value)
        This method is like AttributeWriteValueAdvanced.setValue(Object) but will NOT set the original value and will set the modified to true (instead of false).
        Specified by:
        setValueForUser in interface AttributeWriteValueAdvanced<Void>
        Parameters:
        value - is the value to set.

        public void setValue(Void value,
                     boolean forUser)
        This is the generic variant of AttributeWriteValueAdvanced.setValue(Object) and AttributeWriteValueAdvanced.setValueForUser(Object).
        NOTE:
        To make your code expressive please only use this method for generic situations where forUser is dynamic.
        Specified by:
        setValue in interface AttributeWriteValueAdvanced<Void>
        Parameters:
        value - is the new value to set.
        forUser - true for the semantics of AttributeWriteValueAdvanced.setValueForUser(Object), false for AttributeWriteValueAdvanced.setValue(Object).

        This method resets this widget. It is a convenience method for the following code. 
        setValue(AttributeReadValueAdvanced.getOriginalValue())
        Specified by:

      • getValue

        public Void getValue()
        This method gets the value of this object. This will typically be a newly created object.
        ATTENTION:
        If the current value entered by the user can NOT be parsed, this method will catch and ignore the exception and return null instead. If you want to do validation and give feedback to the user please use AttributeReadValueAdvanced.getValueOrException(Object) instead. However, there are higher-level ways to do this such as getValueAndValidate.
        Specified by:
        getValue in interface AttributeReadValueAdvanced<Void>
        Specified by:
        getValue in interface AttributeReadValue<Void>
        Returns:
        the value of this object. May be null unless otherwise stated.

      • getValueOrException

        public Void getValueOrException(Void template)
                         throws RuntimeException
        This method is like AttributeReadValueAdvanced.getValue() but does NOT catch exceptions while parsing the value from the user input. Additionally it allows to provide a template object that gets populated. This allows advanced features with polymorphism as you can also provide a sub-class of <VALUE>.
        Specified by:
        getValueOrException in interface AttributeReadValueAdvanced<Void>
        Parameters:
        template - is the object where the data is filled in. May also be null - then this method will create a new instance.
        Returns:
        the current value of this widget. May be null if empty. If the value type is String the empty String has to be returned if no value has been entered. In case <VALUE> is a mutable object (java bean) and template is NOT null, this method is supposed to return template.
        Throws:
        RuntimeException - if the entered value is invalid (e.g. paring caused a NumberFormatException).

      • getOriginalValue

        public Void getOriginalValue()
        This method gets the last value that has been set. After calling AttributeWriteValueAdvanced.setValue(Object) the value can be modified (by the user in case of a widget). Then calls to AttributeReadValueAdvanced.getValue() will return the current value with its potential modifications (as a new object). This method will ensure to get the value that was set before by the program.
        ATTENTION:
        The original value shall never be modified to avoid undesired side effects. Various features such as AttributeWriteValueAdvanced.resetValue() rely on this fact. Therefore AttributeReadValueAdvanced.getValue() will always return a new instance.
        Specified by:
        getOriginalValue in interface AttributeReadValueAdvanced<Void>
        Returns:
        the original value.

      • getRecentValue

        public Void getRecentValue()
        Specified by:
        getRecentValue in interface UiDataBinding<Void>
        Returns:
        the last value that has been set via AttributeWriteValueAdvanced.setValue(Object, boolean). This is the original value or the value that has been set for the user after the original value was set for the last time.

      • addValidator

        public void addValidator(ValueValidator<? super Void> validator)
        This method adds the given ValueValidator to this object. All ValueValidators are invoked in the same order as they are added by this method. They are invoked no matter if the previous ValueValidators failed or succeeded. You should always design ValueValidators in a robust and reusable way (e.g. a range validator should accept null as valid input so it can be used for both mandatory and optional fields).
        Specified by:
        addValidator in interface HasValueValidators<Void>
        Parameters:
        validator - is the ValueValidator to add.

      • removeValidator

        public boolean removeValidator(ValueValidator<? super Void> validator)
        This method removes the given ValueValidator from this object.
        ATTENTION:
        Having dynamic validators is an exotic case that should be avoided. This feature is provided but not recommended.
        Specified by:
        removeValidator in interface HasValueValidators<Void>
        Parameters:
        validator - is the ValueValidator to remove.
        Returns:
        true if the ValueValidator has actually been removed, false otherwise (it has NOT previously been added).

      • validate

        public boolean validate(ValidationState state)
        This method performs the actual validation.
        Specified by:
        validate in interface AbstractValidatableObject
        Parameters:
        state - is the ValidationState. Shall initially be created as new instance and passed on in case of recursive validations. May also be null and will then be created internally (in case you do not need more feedback than a boolean result).
        Returns:
        true if the validation of this object has been successful, false otherwise (if there are validation failures).

      • doValidate

        public boolean doValidate(ValidationState state,
                          Void value)
        This method performs the actual validation using the registered validators. It is called from AbstractUiWidget (method doValidate) that itself is called from AbstractValidatableObject.validate(ValidationState).
        Specified by:
        doValidate in interface UiDataBinding<Void>
        Parameters:
        state - is the ValidationState. Must NOT be null.
        value - is the current value of this object that has already be determined.
        Returns:
        true if the validation was successful, false otherwise (if there are validation failures).

      • bind

        public <P> void bind(TypedProperty<P> property,
                     UiWidgetWithValue<P> widget)
        This method binds the given widget to the given property. This will have to following effects:
        • UiFeatureValueAndValidation.getValueDirect(Object, net.sf.mmm.util.validation.api.ValidationState) and therefore all other getValue* methods will automatically read the value of the given widget and set it to the given property of the <VALUE> to return.
        • AttributeWriteValueAdvanced.setValue(Object, boolean) and therefore all other setValue* methods will automatically get the property-value of the given property from the <VALUE>-object and set that property-value to the given widget.
        Specified by:
        bind in interface UiDataBinding<Void>
        Type Parameters:
        P - is the generic type of the property value.
        Parameters:
        property - is the TypedProperty representing the property to bind. It has to be a property of <VALUE>.
        widget - is the value based widget to bind to the given property.
        See Also:
        UiDataBinding.createAndBind(TypedProperty)

      • createAndBind

        public <P> UiWidgetWithValue<P> createAndBind(TypedProperty<P> property)
        This method creates a value based widget that is to be added as child of the widget owning this data-binding. This will have to following effects:
        • A new widget is created according to the property type via UiWidgetFactoryDatatype and can be highly customized.
        • The label is automatically derived from the property including localization. Therefore you need to define a NlsBundleWithLookup (see UiConfiguration.getLabelLookup()) mapping the title with the properties to the localized display labels.
        • A ValueValidator is automatically created for the property based on JSR 303 and will be added to the new widget.
        • Mandatory fields are marked as such (appearance can be customized in CSS).
        • If the input field is a UiWidgetRangeField the minimum and maximum value is set in case JSR 303 constraints such as Min, DecimalMin, Max, and DecimalMax are present. In the example the property foo will be rendered as an integer spin box for the value range from -5 to +5.
        • Also, primitive types are also automatically considered as mandatory as they can not be null.
        • The new widget is automatically bound to the given property.
        Specified by:
        createAndBind in interface UiDataBinding<Void>
        Type Parameters:
        P - is the generic type of the property value.
        Parameters:
        property - is the TypedProperty representing the property to bind. It has to be a property of <VALUE> and contain its property type.
        Returns:
        a new widget to view and edit the given property. It will already been bound.

      • createAndBind

        public <P> UiWidgetWithValue<P> createAndBind(TypedProperty<P> property,
                                              String label)
        This method is like UiDataBinding.createAndBind(TypedProperty) but using the given label instead of deriving it automatically.
        Specified by:
        createAndBind in interface UiDataBinding<Void>
        Type Parameters:
        P - is the generic type of the property value.
        Parameters:
        property - is the TypedProperty representing the property to bind. It has to be a property of <VALUE> and contain its property type.
        label - is the label to use for the widget. See UiWidgetField.getLabel().
        Returns:
        a new widget to view and edit the given property. It will already been bound.

      • setModified

        public void setModified(boolean modified)
        This method sets the modified attribute programatically.
        ATTENTION:
        This interface and this method is NOT intended to be used by API users. The strategy how to determine if something is modified should be an implementation secret (another strategy may be to get the value and check if it is equal to the original value what is however not as robust). Instead methods such as AttributeWriteValueAdvanced.setValueForUser(Object) should be provided for API users.
        Specified by:
        setModified in interface AttributeWriteModified
        Parameters:
        modified - is the new value of AttributeReadModified.isModified().
        See Also:
        AttributeReadModified.isModified()

      • isModified

        public boolean isModified()
        This method determines if this object (or more precisely its value) is modified. This means that the object has been modified (via a the user interface) since it's value was programatically set for the last time. Often this is also called dirty. A composite object is also modified if one of its children are modified.
        NOTE:
        If the object's value is changed by the end-user to something else but then changed back to its original value it may still remain modified.
        Specified by:
        isModified in interface AttributeReadModified
        Returns:
        true if this object has been modified, false otherwise (if no changes have been made to this object).
        See Also:
        AttributeReadValueAdvanced.getOriginalValue(), AttributeWriteValueAdvanced.setValueForUser(Object)

      • getValidity

        public Boolean getValidity()
        Specified by:
        getValidity in interface UiDataBinding<Void>
        Returns:
        Boolean.TRUE if validation was successful, Boolean.FALSE if validation failed, null if NOT validated (since UiFeatureMessages.clearMessages() or something similar has been called).

      • setValidity

        public void setValidity(Boolean valid)
        This method sets the value of UiDataBinding.getValidity().
        ATTENTION:
        This is an internal method and should NOT be used by external users. Usage has to be compliant with UiDataBinding.getValidity().
        Specified by:
        setValidity in interface UiDataBinding<Void>
        Parameters:
        valid - is the new value for UiDataBinding.getValidity(). May be null.
